body: Tentatively slated for 5.8 M2 for _team discussion_
**Team decision:** Clarify the implementation in the Javadoc of `assertEquals` and `assertNotEquals` similar to `Objects.equal` from the JDK.

rename.from: Assertions.assertNotEquals not working when actual is null and equals overriden
rename.to: Document implementation of assertEquals() and assertNotEquals() regarding equals()

body:
The point of that TestNG issue was that people misuse the assertion methods to check their `equals` implementations ([example for such misuse](https://lgtm.com/query/6157623132776546027/)). Personally I think it would therefore be better to explicitly state that this is not what the assertion methods are intended for; only documenting their implementation might not necessarily prevent people from misusing them, especially when the implications of the implementation are not obvious.

I think it would therefore be better to add something similar to the following to the `Assertions` class documentation instead of describing the implementation details of the assertion methods:
> **Important:** Assertion methods comparing two values for equality, such as `assertEquals`, are *only* intended to test equality for an (un-)expected and an actual result value. They are not designed for testing whether a class correctly implements `equals(Object)`. For example `assertEquals` might return fast when provided with the same object as expected and actual value without calling `equals(Object)` at all.  
Such tests trying to verify the `equals(Object)` implementation should instead be written explicitly and `assertTrue` or `assertFalse` should be used to verify the result, e.g.: `assertTrue(var.equals(var))`, `assertFalse(var.equals(null))`.

What do you think?

I'm not on the JUnit team, but I agree with @Marcono1234's suggestion!

The Truth team have some similar wording in their [`assertThat(...).isEqualTo(...)`](https://truth.dev/api/1.1.2/com/google/common/truth/Subject.html#isEqualTo(java.lang.Object)) doc, so there's precedence for including this sort of information.

issue.title: Mention in Assert javadoc that it is not intended for equals(...) check
issue.body:
Follow-up for #2497
Fixes #2490

### Did you remember to?

- [ ] Add test case(s)
- [ ] Update `CHANGES.txt`
  Not mentioned in there since there is already an entry for 2490 (which did not actually fix the issue).

### Description
Improves the `Assert` documentation by mentioning that it is not designed for verifying `equals(Object)` implementations.
The text is based on https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2567#issuecomment-806626091.

body: @Marcono1234 Sounds good to me! Would you be interested in submitting a PR with that?

issue.title: Clarify intended usage of assert{Not}Equals

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview
Resolves #2567

See https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2567#issuecomment-806626091.

The changes currently only adjust the `Assertions` documentation. Should the user guide be adjusted as well?
And should this also be mentioned in the release notes? It is not a behavior change, so I am not sure how relevant it is for the release notes.

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass

body: @marcphilipp, sorry for the delay, I have created #2632 now.

Shouldn't the last assertion be `assertFalse(actual.equals(null))` as one usually is interested in a well-behaved _actual_?
https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/bd7d03f517dfca3730fbd123c5fd4d4b70930129/junit-jupiter-api/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/Assertions.java#L50-L51

(This can be related to #3120.)

> Shouldn't the last assertion be `assertFalse(actual.equals(null))` as one usually is interested in a well-behaved _actual_?

I wouldn't call it the "last assertion". The "etc." implies that one could continue with that pattern to add `assertFalse(actual.equals(null))` as a 4th assertion along with any other assertions that one deems appropriate.
